title: Pillar tomb
text:
A pillar tomb is a type of monumental <a href="grave">grave</a> wherein the central feature is a single, prominent pillar or column, often made of stone.
Overview.
A number of world cultures incorporated pillars into tomb structures. Examples of such edifices are found in <a href="Lycia">Lycia</a> in <a href="Anatolia">Anatolia</a> (e.g., the <a href="Harpy%20Tomb">Harpy Tomb</a> at <a href="Xanthos">Xanthos</a>), and the <a href="medieval">medieval</a> Muslim <a href="Swahili%20culture">Swahili culture</a> of the <a href="Swahili%20Coast">Swahili Coast</a> (e.g., tombs at <a href="Malindi">Malindi</a> and <a href="Mnarani">Mnarani</a>), which were originally built of <a href="coral%20rag">coral rag</a>, and later of stone.
In the historic town of <a href="Hannassa">Hannassa</a> in southern <a href="Somalia">Somalia</a>, ruins of houses with <a href="arch">arch</a>ways and <a href="courtyard">courtyard</a>s have been found along with pillar tombs, including a rare <a href="octagon">octagon</a>al one. <a href="Port%20Dunford">Port Dunford</a>, situated nearby, also contains a number of ancient ruins, including several pillar tombs. Prior to its collapse, one of these structures' pillars stood high from the ground, making it the tallest of its kind in the region.
